newsitem.title: USA: August retail sales rose weakly.
newsitem.headline: August retail sales rose weakly.

text.p: Sales at retail stores edged up weakly for a second month in a row during August, the Commerce Department said Friday, as an expected rebound in auto sales last month failed to show up.

Total retail sales rose 0.2 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted $205 billion -- well below Wall Street economists' forecasts of a 0.7 percent increase -- after a slight 0.1 percent gain in July.

During August, sales of new cars were up only 0.1 percent to $49.7 billion after being flat in July. New cars account for about one-fifth of total retail sales, so swings in demand strongly affect the overall monthly figures.
Excluding cars, retail sales rose 0.2 percent during each of July and August.

Domestic automakers previously reported brisk sales in August, which led analysts to anticipate a strong rise in overall monthly retail business. Some of the car dealers' sales data may not yet have been captured by the government's monthly survey.
August sales of all types of durable goods, including cars, were up 0.3 percent to $83.8 billion after a 0.2 percent July increase that previously was reported as a 0.4 percent drop.
Sales of nodurable goods gained 0.1 percent in August to $121.2 billion after being unchanged in July.
There were some signs of spending strength in the August report, though not enough to boost overall sales.

Sales by general merchandise stores rose 0.7 percent to $25.9 billion after a 0.2 percent increase in July. At apparel stores, sales of clothing climbed solidly by one percent to $9.5 billion after dropping 0.7 percent in July.
The Olympics were blamed for depressed sales in July, as consumers apparently stayed home to watch television rather than travel to shopping malls.

In its latest Beige Book report on the economy issued on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve said the August back-to-school shopping season was off to a good start and sales in many parts of the country surpassed retailers' expectations.

Sales of building materials fell 0.7 percent last month to $11.4 billion after a 0.2 percent increase in July. Costlier interest rates are expected to slow the housing industry in the second half of the year.
Sales by food stores dropped 0.7 percent in August to $35.2 billion following a 0.9 percent July rise.
Gasoline service station sales fell 0.9 percent to $12.9 billion after plunging 1.8 percent in July.
